revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{For|other people named Stephen Grant|Stephen Grant (disambiguation)}}
'''Stephen Grant''' (born 2 July 1973 in [[Brighton]]) is a British [[comedian]], comedy writer, and radio presenter. He hosts the Krater Comedy Club at [[Komedia]] in Brighton, which won the [[Chortle Awards|Chortle Award]] for Best Comedy Club in the South for 2002–2006, 2008, and 2011–2014.<ref>[http://www.chortle.co.uk/venues/28/south_east_surrey,_kent_and_sussex/36/brighton_komedia Brighton Komedia]. ''[[Chortle (website)|Chortle]]''. Retrieved 22 July 2016.</ref> In 2008 and 2011, Grant won the Chortle Award for Best Compère.<ref>[http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/s/354/stephen_grant Stephen Grant]. ''[[Chortle (website)|Chortle]]''. Retrieved 22 July 2016.</ref>
In the early 2000s, Grant wrote and hosted several documentaries for [[BBC2]].<ref name=bcg>Hawkins, Si. [http://www.comedy.co.uk/live/circuit_training/stephen_grant_interview/ "Circuit Training 28: Stephen Grant"]. ''British Comedy Guide''. 31 January 2011.</ref> He also wrote gags for [[BBC Radio 1]]'s daytime DJs for many years.<ref name=bcg />
Of his one-hour comedy routine, ''[[The Stage]]'' wrote in 2004 that "Stephen Grant is nothing if not original. Supremely intelligent yet utterly accessible, his charm lies in the quick-fire speed of his mind."<ref>Thompson, Helena. [https://web.archive.org/web/20081202054804/http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/4025/stephen-grant "Stephen Grant"]. ''[[The Stage]]''. 2 September 2004.</ref> Grant has released two live comedy DVDs: ''Stephen Grant: Live at the Theatre Royal Brighton'' and ''Stephen Grant: Taken for Granted''.<ref>[http://www.stephengrant.com/shop/ Shop]. ''StephenGrant.com''. Retrieved 22 July 2016.</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20151123073020/http://www.timeout.com/london/film/100-best-comedy-movies-contributors-f-g 100 best comedy movies – contributors F-G]. ''[[Time Out London]]''. Retrieved November 2015.</ref> In addition to emceeing in Brighton, he also hosts at [[The Comedy Store (London)|The Comedy Store]] in London.<ref>[http://thecomedystore.co.uk/london/comedian/stephen-grant/ Stephen Grant]. [[The Comedy Store (London)|The Comedy Store]]. Retrieved 22 July 2016.</ref><ref>[https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/london-we-are-funny-mcing-workshop-with-stephen-grant-tickets-25232896272?aff=ebapi LONDON We Are Funny "MCing" Workshop with Stephen Grant]. ''EventBrite.co.uk''. Retrieved 22 July 2016</ref> He has performed around the UK and all over the world,<ref name=bcg /> and is a frequent stand-up comic at the [[Edinburgh Fringe]].
Grant made headlines in several major national newspapers in 2010, when he won a lawsuit in which his ex-wife tried to prevent him from joking about their divorce.<ref>Gammel, Caroline. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/8035312/Comedian-wins-legal-battle-to-joke-about-divorce.html "Comedian wins legal battle to joke about divorce"]. ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]''. 1 October 2010.</ref><ref>Lister, David. [https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/columnists/david-lister/david-lister-where-theres-love-theres-material-for-standup-comics-2101853.html "Where there's love, there's material for stand-up comics"]. ''[[The Independent]]''. 8 October 2010.</ref><ref>Logan, Brian. [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/theatreblog/2010/oct/04/comedian-ex-wife-stephen-grant-jokes "Long live those mother-in-law (and ex-wife) jokes"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. 4 October 2010.</ref>
